blurb: The “Linked Discourses with Vaṅgīsa” contains 12 discourses with verses spoken by Vaṅgīsa, the most renowned poet of early Buddhism. His verses have a sophistication and personal vulnerability that stamp them as perhaps the most distinctive literary voice of the early texts. Several of these discourses speak of his insecurities and struggles, and how he was helped to overcome them. Others speak from his joyous devotion to the Buddha and the Saṅgha, and of his final triumph.

translated_title: The Chapter with the Poet Vaṅgīsa

blurb: Enticed by the sight of beautiful women, the newly ordained monk Vaṅgīsa dispels desire and celebrates his commitment to the spiritual path in verse.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Vaṅgīsa is troubled again by lust, but manages to dispel it through his own efforts. His verse speak of the way of the renunciate, letting go of desire and wrong views, and dedicated to ethical conduct and seclusion.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: As a renowned poet, Vaṅgīsa looked down on less skilled mendicants. Ashamed of his conceit, he exhorted himself in verse to be humble and at peace.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Troubled once more by lust, Vaṅgīsa turned to Ānanda for support. Ānanda tells him to shift his perception so that beautiful things no longer seem so.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: The Buddha gives a simple teaching on four qualities of good speech. Vaṅgīsa is inspired to utter a more elaborate set of verses on the topic, praising especially the speech of the Buddha that leads to the Deathless.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Seeing Sāriputta speak on the Dhamma, and the rapt attention of the Saṅgha, Vaṅgīsa comes out with verses in his praise.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

alt_volpages: PTS (2nd ed) 1.411, PTS (2nd ed) 1.412, PTS (2nd ed) 1.413, PTS (2nd ed) 1.414
blurb: On the Pavāraṇā day at the end of the rains retreat, the Buddha invites the Saṅgha to admonish him. But not only is the Buddha faultless, so are all the 500 monks present. Vaṅgīsa is inspired to utter a elaborate praise of the Buddha.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

alt_volpages: PTS (2nd ed) 1.415, PTS (2nd ed) 1.416, PTS (2nd ed) 1.417
blurb: Seeing the Buddha speak on the Dhamma, and the rapt attention of the Saṅgha, Vaṅgīsa comes out with verses in his praise. When asked if the verses were spontaneous, he replies that they were, and the Buddha invites him to speak further.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Aññā Koṇḍañña, the very first disciple to realize the Dhamma, comes to visit the Buddha after long in seclusion. Inspired, Vaṅgīsa speaks verses in his praise.

translations.author: ইন্দ্রগুপ্ত ভিক্ষু, বঙ্গীস ভিক্ষু, অজিত ভিক্ষু, সীবক ভিক্ষু

translations.lang_name: မြန်မာဘာသာ
translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Vaṅgīsa speaks in praise of Moggallāna and the Saṅgha.

translations.author: Pitaka Myanmar Translation

blurb: Vaṅgīsa says the Buddha, like the moon or the sun, outshines the whole world.
